attributes.description:
FSC Cerification: http://info.fsc.org/Detail?id=a0240000006swJYAAY

In 1917, Dominion Blank Book Co. Ltd. was incorporated as the Canadian subsidiary of the National Blank Book Company of Holyoke, Massachusetts (later Avery Dennison), a Canadian manufacturer of stock business forms, accounting supplies, planners and note-taking products. Quebec-based Dominion Blueline Inc. has been in business for over 85 years and distributes to the Canadian, U.S. and Mexican markets. In September 1998, Rediform was acquired by Dominion Blueline Inc.
attributes.address: 230 Rue Foch, Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu, QC J3B 5W9, Canada
attributes.title: DOMINION BLUELINE INC.

attributes.description:
According to CalRecycle.ca.gov 
10% minimum post-consumer paper, up to 50% recovered paper, up to 60% Total Recycled Content (TRC).

UPC Record
http://www.upcdatabase.com/item/073333531084

Rediform is an American company that manufactures and distributes office products. Rediform was established in 1956 as a division of Moore Corporation, a global company and printer of business forms. Rediform became a strategic distributor of Moore products through wholesale and retail channels in the United States. In December 1998, Rediform acquired the Wilson Jones line of business form products from Acco U.S.A. In July 1999, Rediform also acquired the Avery telephone message book business from Avery Dennison. In November 2003, Rediform signed a multi-year license agreement with Avery Dennison Worldwide Office Products for the worldwide exclusive sale, distribution and manufacture of the National Brand note-taking and accounting supplies business.

attributes.description:
Printed, folded, collated, cut, assembled, sewn, and glued in Mexico at a maquiladora near the US/Mexico border.

Probably manufactured at Blueline Manufacturing de Mexico S.A. de C.V. 

in Ciudad Acuña, also known as Acuña, (originally Garza located in the Mexican state of Coahuila

www.bluelineinc.com

(877) 773-53-18

Maquiladora (wikipedia): manufacturing operations in a free trade zone (FTZ), where factories import material and equipment on a duty-free and tariff-free basis for assembly, processing, or manufacturing and then export the assembled, processed and/or manufactured products, sometimes back to the raw materials' country of origin.
